text:
Last day of Hajj ends on tragic note 700 die 900 injured in stampede
The annual Islamic pilgrimage Hajj in Mecca finished on a very tragic note. 700 people were killed and nearly 900 others were injured among the two million who gathered for the day of sacrifice.
The stampede occurred in the early hours of Tuesday during the ritual of “stoning the devil” about two miles in the tent city in Mina from the holy city in Mecca.
The sight was ghastly as seen in television footage where bodies were piled over bodies. Pilgrims helped the injured by carrying them to safety.
The place has suffered some management crisis in the past. Hundreds have been killed in Hajj in similar way and recently a crane collapse also led to the death of 100 people in a major Islamic holy site, the Grand Mosque in Mecca. In 2006, a stampede killed at least 363 people. In the 1980s and 1990s there was a stampede where hundreds died as pilgrims passed a crowded bottleneck area leading to the small pillars.
Crown Prince Mohammad bin Nayef bin Abdulaziz held an emergency meeting to discuss the stampede, according to the Saudi Press Agency. He has also ordered an enquiry.
Saudi King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud later ordered a review of the country’s plans during Hajj. The king said that regardless of the incident, the Hajj season will not stop. The concerned entities will be re-evaluated.
The incident occurred when the pilgrims were walking towards the largest pillar when there was a sudden surge in the crowd. This caused a large number of people to fall. They were heading for the ritual where pilgrims throw stones at three pillars in a re-enactment of when the Prophet Abraham stoned the devil and rejected his temptations, according to Muslim traditions.
The Saudi government erected three massive pillars specially for Hajj that was completed at $1.2 billion along with a five-story bridge nearby where pilgrims can toss stones. It was meant to be a roomier atmosphere and a more efficient way to accommodate the faithful. But when it comes to managing 2 million people it is difficult to keep track. The ritual is practiced for two days. Pilgrims stone three pillars in Mina which is believed to be the devil who tried to dissuade Abraham from obeying God’s order to slaughter his son. As tradition goes it was God testing Abraham’s faith in him and he then gave Abraham a ram to slaughter instead.
The Hajj is an obligation to each Muslim who can make it to the holy city. The pilgrimage is conducted over a period of 5 days. People are garbed in white and symbolise equality and unity before God. A circular procession around Kaaba, the Islamic holy shrine is conducted.
